trans-unit.source: Access datasets with Machine Learning Python client library | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Access datasets with Machine Learning Python client library | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Install and use the Python client library to access and manage Azure Machine Learning data securely from a local Python environment.
trans-unit.target: Install and use the Python client library to access and manage Azure Machine Learning data securely from a local Python environment.

trans-unit.source: Access datasets with Python using the Azure Machine Learning Python client library
trans-unit.target: Access datasets with Python using the Azure Machine Learning Python client library

trans-unit.source: The preview of Microsoft Azure Machine Learning Python client library can enable secure access to your Azure Machine Learning datasets from a local Python environment and enables the creation and management of datasets in workspace.
trans-unit.target: The preview of Microsoft Azure Machine Learning Python client library can enable secure access to your Azure Machine Learning datasets from a local Python environment and enables the creation and management of datasets in workspace.

trans-unit.source: This topic provides instructions on how to:
trans-unit.target: This topic provides instructions on how to:

trans-unit.source: install the Machine Learning Python client library
trans-unit.target: install the Machine Learning Python client library

trans-unit.source: access and upload datasets, including instructions on how to get authorization to access Azure Machine Learning datasets from your local Python environment
trans-unit.target: access and upload datasets, including instructions on how to get authorization to access Azure Machine Learning datasets from your local Python environment

trans-unit.source: access intermediate datasets from experiments
trans-unit.target: access intermediate datasets from experiments

trans-unit.source: use the Python client library to enumerate datasets, access metadata, read the contents of a dataset, create new datasets and update existing datasets
trans-unit.target: use the Python client library to enumerate datasets, access metadata, read the contents of a dataset, create new datasets and update existing datasets

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: The Python client library has been tested under the following environments:
trans-unit.target: The Python client library has been tested under the following environments:

trans-unit.source: Windows, Mac and Linux
trans-unit.target: Windows, Mac and Linux

trans-unit.source: Python 2.7, 3.3 and 3.4
trans-unit.target: Python 2.7, 3.3 and 3.4

trans-unit.source: It has a dependency on the following packages:
trans-unit.target: It has a dependency on the following packages:

trans-unit.source: requests
trans-unit.target: requests

trans-unit.source: python-dateutil
trans-unit.target: python-dateutil

trans-unit.source: pandas
trans-unit.target: pandas

trans-unit.source: We recommend using a Python distribution such as [Anaconda](http://continuum.io/downloads#all) or [Canopy](https://store.enthought.com/downloads/), which come with Python, IPython and the three packages listed above installed.
trans-unit.target: We recommend using a Python distribution such as [Anaconda](http://continuum.io/downloads#all) or [Canopy](https://store.enthought.com/downloads/), which come with Python, IPython and the three packages listed above installed.

trans-unit.source: Although IPython is not strictly required, it is a great environment for manipulating and visualizing data interactively.
trans-unit.target: Although IPython is not strictly required, it is a great environment for manipulating and visualizing data interactively.

trans-unit.source: How to install the Azure Machine Learning Python client library
trans-unit.target: How to install the Azure Machine Learning Python client library

trans-unit.source: The Azure Machine Learning Python client library must also be installed to complete the tasks outlined in this topic.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Machine Learning Python client library must also be installed to complete the tasks outlined in this topic.

trans-unit.source: It is available from the [Python Package Index](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/azureml).
trans-unit.target: It is available from the [Python Package Index](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/azureml).

trans-unit.source: To install it in your Python environment, run the following command from your local Python environment:
trans-unit.target: To install it in your Python environment, run the following command from your local Python environment:

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can download and install from the sources on [github](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-ClientLibrary-Python).
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can download and install from the sources on [github](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-ClientLibrary-Python).

trans-unit.source: If you have git installed on your machine, you can use pip to install directly from the git repository:
trans-unit.target: If you have git installed on your machine, you can use pip to install directly from the git repository:

trans-unit.source: Use Studio Code snippets to access datasets
trans-unit.target: Use Studio Code snippets to access datasets

trans-unit.source: The Python client library gives you programmatic access to your existing datasets from experiments that have been run.
trans-unit.target: The Python client library gives you programmatic access to your existing datasets from experiments that have been run.

trans-unit.source: From the Studio web interface, you can generate code snippets that include all the necessary information to download and deserialize datasets as Pandas DataFrame objects on your location machine.
trans-unit.target: From the Studio web interface, you can generate code snippets that include all the necessary information to download and deserialize datasets as Pandas DataFrame objects on your location machine.

trans-unit.source: Security for data access
trans-unit.target: Security for data access

trans-unit.source: The code snippets provided by Studio for use with the Python client library includes your workspace id and authorization token.
trans-unit.target: The code snippets provided by Studio for use with the Python client library includes your workspace id and authorization token.

trans-unit.source: These provide full access to your workspace and must be protect, like a password.
trans-unit.target: These provide full access to your workspace and must be protect, like a password.

trans-unit.source: For security reasons, the code snippet functionality is only available to users that have their role set as **Owner** for the workspace.
trans-unit.target: For security reasons, the code snippet functionality is only available to users that have their role set as **Owner** for the workspace.

trans-unit.source: Your role is displayed in Azure Machine Learning Studio on the **USERS** page under **Settings**.
trans-unit.target: Your role is displayed in Azure Machine Learning Studio on the **USERS** page under **Settings**.

trans-unit.source: ![Security][security]
trans-unit.target: ![Security][security]

trans-unit.source: If your role is not set as **Owner**, you can either request to be re-invited as an owner, or ask the owner of the workspace to provide you with the code snippet.
trans-unit.target: If your role is not set as **Owner**, you can either request to be re-invited as an owner, or ask the owner of the workspace to provide you with the code snippet.

trans-unit.source: To obtain the authorization token, you can do one of the following:
trans-unit.target: To obtain the authorization token, you can do one of the following:

trans-unit.source: Ask for a token from an owner.
trans-unit.target: Ask for a token from an owner.

trans-unit.source: Owners can access their authorization tokens from the Settings page of their workspace in Studio.
trans-unit.target: Owners can access their authorization tokens from the Settings page of their workspace in Studio.

trans-unit.source: Select **Settings** from the left pane and click on **AUTHORIZATION TOKENS** to see the primary and secondary tokens.
trans-unit.target: Select **Settings** from the left pane and click on **AUTHORIZATION TOKENS** to see the primary and secondary tokens.

trans-unit.source: Although either the primary or the secondary authorization tokens can be used in the code snippet, it is recommended that owners only share the secondary authorization tokens.
trans-unit.target: Although either the primary or the secondary authorization tokens can be used in the code snippet, it is recommended that owners only share the secondary authorization tokens.

trans-unit.source: Ask to be promoted to role of owner.
trans-unit.target: Ask to be promoted to role of owner.

trans-unit.source: To do this, a current owner of the workspace needs to first remove you from the workspace then re-invite you to it as an owner.
trans-unit.target: To do this, a current owner of the workspace needs to first remove you from the workspace then re-invite you to it as an owner.

trans-unit.source: Once developers have obtained the workspace id and authorization token, they will be able to access the workspace using the code snippet regardless of their role.
trans-unit.target: Once developers have obtained the workspace id and authorization token, they will be able to access the workspace using the code snippet regardless of their role.

trans-unit.source: Authorization tokens are managed on the **AUTHORIZATION TOKENS** page under **SETTINGS**.
trans-unit.target: Authorization tokens are managed on the **AUTHORIZATION TOKENS** page under **SETTINGS**.

trans-unit.source: You can regenerate them, but this procedure will revoke access to the previous token.
trans-unit.target: You can regenerate them, but this procedure will revoke access to the previous token.

trans-unit.source: Access datasets from a local Python application
trans-unit.target: Access datasets from a local Python application

trans-unit.source: In Machine Learning Studio, click on **DATASETS** in the navigation bar on the left.
trans-unit.target: In Machine Learning Studio, click on **DATASETS** in the navigation bar on the left.

trans-unit.source: Select the dataset you would like to access.
trans-unit.target: Select the dataset you would like to access.

trans-unit.source: You can select any of the datasets from the **MY DATASETS** list or from the **SAMPLES** list.
trans-unit.target: You can select any of the datasets from the **MY DATASETS** list or from the **SAMPLES** list.

trans-unit.source: From the bottom toolbar, click on **Generate Data Access Code**.
trans-unit.target: From the bottom toolbar, click on **Generate Data Access Code**.

trans-unit.source: Note that this button will be disabled if the data is in a format incompatible with the Python client library.
trans-unit.target: Note that this button will be disabled if the data is in a format incompatible with the Python client library.

trans-unit.source: ![Datasets][datasets]
trans-unit.target: ![Datasets][datasets]

trans-unit.source: Select the code snippet from the window that appears and copy it to your clipboard.
trans-unit.target: Select the code snippet from the window that appears and copy it to your clipboard.

trans-unit.source: ![Access Code][dataset-access-code]
trans-unit.target: ![Access Code][dataset-access-code]

trans-unit.source: Paste the code into the notebook of you local Python application.
trans-unit.target: Paste the code into the notebook of you local Python application.

trans-unit.source: ![Notebook][ipython-dataset]
trans-unit.target: ![Notebook][ipython-dataset]

trans-unit.source: Access intermediate datasets from Machine Learning experiments
trans-unit.target: Access intermediate datasets from Machine Learning experiments

trans-unit.source: After an experiment is run in the Machine Learning Studio, it is possible to access the intermediate datasets from the output nodes of modules.
trans-unit.target: After an experiment is run in the Machine Learning Studio, it is possible to access the intermediate datasets from the output nodes of modules.

trans-unit.source: Intermediate datasets are data that has been created and used for intermediate steps when a model tool has been run.
trans-unit.target: Intermediate datasets are data that has been created and used for intermediate steps when a model tool has been run.

trans-unit.source: Intermediate datasets can be accessed as long as the data format is compatible with the Python client library.
trans-unit.target: Intermediate datasets can be accessed as long as the data format is compatible with the Python client library.

trans-unit.source: The following formats are supported (constants for these are in the `azureml.DataTypeIds` class):
trans-unit.target: The following formats are supported (constants for these are in the `azureml.DataTypeIds` class):

trans-unit.source: PlainText
trans-unit.target: PlainText

trans-unit.source: GenericCSV
trans-unit.target: GenericCSV

trans-unit.source: GenericTSV
trans-unit.target: GenericTSV

trans-unit.source: GenericCSVNoHeader
trans-unit.target: GenericCSVNoHeader

trans-unit.source: GenericTSVNoHeader
trans-unit.target: GenericTSVNoHeader

trans-unit.source: You can determine the format by hovering over a module output node.
trans-unit.target: You can determine the format by hovering over a module output node.

trans-unit.source: It is displayed along with the node name, in a tooltip.
trans-unit.target: It is displayed along with the node name, in a tooltip.

trans-unit.source: Some of the modules, such as the [Split][split] module, output to a format named `Dataset`, which is not supported by the Python client library.
trans-unit.target: Some of the modules, such as the [Split][split] module, output to a format named `Dataset`, which is not supported by the Python client library.

trans-unit.source: ![Dataset Format][dataset-format]
trans-unit.target: ![Dataset Format][dataset-format]

trans-unit.source: You'll need to use a conversion module, such as [Convert to CSV][convert-to-csv], to get an output into a supported format.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to use a conversion module, such as [Convert to CSV][convert-to-csv], to get an output into a supported format.

trans-unit.source: ![GenericCSV Format][csv-format]
trans-unit.target: ![GenericCSV Format][csv-format]

trans-unit.source: The following steps show an example that creates an experiment, runs it and accesses the intermediate dataset.
trans-unit.target: The following steps show an example that creates an experiment, runs it and accesses the intermediate dataset.

trans-unit.source: Create a new experiment.
trans-unit.target: Create a new experiment.

trans-unit.source: Insert an **Adult Census Income Binary Classification dataset** module.
trans-unit.target: Insert an **Adult Census Income Binary Classification dataset** module.

trans-unit.source: Insert a [Split][split] module, and connect its input to the dataset module output.
trans-unit.target: Insert a [Split][split] module, and connect its input to the dataset module output.

trans-unit.source: Insert a [Convert to CSV][convert-to-csv] module and connect its input to one of the [Split][split] module outputs.
trans-unit.target: Insert a [Convert to CSV][convert-to-csv] module and connect its input to one of the [Split][split] module outputs.

trans-unit.source: Save the experiment, run it, and wait for it to finish running.
trans-unit.target: Save the experiment, run it, and wait for it to finish running.

trans-unit.source: Click on the output node on the [Convert to CSV][convert-to-csv] module.
trans-unit.target: Click on the output node on the [Convert to CSV][convert-to-csv] module.

trans-unit.source: A context menu will appear, select **Generate Data Access Code**.
trans-unit.target: A context menu will appear, select **Generate Data Access Code**.

trans-unit.source: ![Context Menu][experiment]
trans-unit.target: ![Context Menu][experiment]

trans-unit.source: A window will appear.
trans-unit.target: A window will appear.

trans-unit.source: Select the code snippet and copy it to your clipboard.
trans-unit.target: Select the code snippet and copy it to your clipboard.

trans-unit.source: ![Access Code][intermediate-dataset-access-code]
trans-unit.target: ![Access Code][intermediate-dataset-access-code]

trans-unit.source: Paste the code in your notebook.
trans-unit.target: Paste the code in your notebook.

trans-unit.source: ![Notebook][ipython-intermediate-dataset]
trans-unit.target: ![Notebook][ipython-intermediate-dataset]

trans-unit.source: You can visualize the data using matplotlib.
trans-unit.target: You can visualize the data using matplotlib.

trans-unit.source: This displays in a histogram for the age column:
trans-unit.target: This displays in a histogram for the age column:

trans-unit.source: ![Histogram][ipython-histogram]
trans-unit.target: ![Histogram][ipython-histogram]

trans-unit.source: Use the Machine Learning Python client library to access, read, create, and manage datasets
trans-unit.target: Use the Machine Learning Python client library to access, read, create, and manage datasets

trans-unit.target: Workspace

trans-unit.source: Provide the `Workspace` class with your workspace id and authorization token to create an instance:
trans-unit.target: Provide the `Workspace` class with your workspace id and authorization token to create an instance:

trans-unit.source: Metadata
trans-unit.target: Metadata

trans-unit.source: Datasets have metadata, in addition to content.
trans-unit.target: Datasets have metadata, in addition to content.

trans-unit.source: (Intermediate datasets are an exception to this rule and do not have any metadata.)
trans-unit.target: (Intermediate datasets are an exception to this rule and do not have any metadata.)

trans-unit.source: Some metadata values are assigned by the user at creation time:
trans-unit.target: Some metadata values are assigned by the user at creation time:

trans-unit.source: Others are values assigned by Azure ML:
trans-unit.target: Others are values assigned by Azure ML:

trans-unit.source: See the `SourceDataset` class for more on the available metadata.
trans-unit.target: See the `SourceDataset` class for more on the available metadata.

trans-unit.source: Read contents
trans-unit.target: Read contents

trans-unit.source: The code snippets provided by Machine Learning Studio automatically download and deserialize the dataset to a Pandas DataFrame object.
trans-unit.target: The code snippets provided by Machine Learning Studio automatically download and deserialize the dataset to a Pandas DataFrame object.

trans-unit.source: This is done with the `to_dataframe` method:
trans-unit.target: This is done with the `to_dataframe` method:

trans-unit.source: If you prefer to download the raw data, and perform the deserialization yourself, that is an option.
trans-unit.target: If you prefer to download the raw data, and perform the deserialization yourself, that is an option.

trans-unit.source: At the moment, this is the only option for formats such as 'ARFF', which the Python client library cannot deserialize.
trans-unit.target: At the moment, this is the only option for formats such as 'ARFF', which the Python client library cannot deserialize.

trans-unit.source: To read the contents as text:
trans-unit.target: To read the contents as text:

trans-unit.source: To read the contents as binary:
trans-unit.target: To read the contents as binary:

trans-unit.source: You can also just open a stream to the contents:
trans-unit.target: You can also just open a stream to the contents:

trans-unit.source: Create a new dataset
trans-unit.target: Create a new dataset

trans-unit.source: The Python client library allow you to upload datasets from your Python program.
trans-unit.target: The Python client library allow you to upload datasets from your Python program.

trans-unit.source: These datasets will be available for use in your workspace.
trans-unit.target: These datasets will be available for use in your workspace.

trans-unit.source: If you have your data in a Pandas DataFrame, use the following code:
trans-unit.target: If you have your data in a Pandas DataFrame, use the following code:

trans-unit.target: If your data is already serialized, you can use:

trans-unit.target: The Python client library are able to serialize a Pandas DataFrame to the following formats (constants for these are in the `azureml.DataTypeIds` class):

trans-unit.target: PlainText

trans-unit.target: GenericCSV

trans-unit.source: GenericTSV
trans-unit.target: GenericTSV

trans-unit.target: GenericCSVNoHeader

trans-unit.source: Update an existing dataset
trans-unit.target: Update an existing dataset

trans-unit.source: If you try to upload a new dataset with a name that matches an existing dataset, you'll get a conflict error.
trans-unit.target: If you try to upload a new dataset with a name that matches an existing dataset, you'll get a conflict error.

trans-unit.source: To update an existing dataset, you first need to get a reference to the existing dataset:
trans-unit.target: To update an existing dataset, you first need to get a reference to the existing dataset:

trans-unit.source: Then use `update_from_dataframe` to serialize and replace the contents of the dataset on Azure:
trans-unit.target: Then use `update_from_dataframe` to serialize and replace the contents of the dataset on Azure:

trans-unit.source: If you want to serialize the data to a different format, specify a value for the optional `data_type_id` parameter.
trans-unit.target: If you want to serialize the data to a different format, specify a value for the optional `data_type_id` parameter.

trans-unit.source: You can optionally set a new description by specifying a value for the `description` parameter.
trans-unit.target: You can optionally set a new description by specifying a value for the `description` parameter.

trans-unit.source: You can optionally set a new name by specifying a value for the `name` parameter.
trans-unit.target: You can optionally set a new name by specifying a value for the `name` parameter.

trans-unit.source: From now on, you'll retrieve the dataset using the new name only.
trans-unit.target: From now on, you'll retrieve the dataset using the new name only.

trans-unit.source: The following code updates the data, name and description.
trans-unit.target: The following code updates the data, name and description.

trans-unit.source: The `data_type_id`, `name` and `description` parameters are all optional, and default to their previous value.
trans-unit.target: The `data_type_id`, `name` and `description` parameters are all optional, and default to their previous value.

trans-unit.source: The `dataframe` parameter is always required.
trans-unit.target: The `dataframe` parameter is always required.

trans-unit.source: If your data is already serialized, use `update_from_raw_data` instead of `update_from_dataframe`.
trans-unit.target: If your data is already serialized, use `update_from_raw_data` instead of `update_from_dataframe`.

trans-unit.source: It works similarly, you just pass in `raw_data` instead of `dataframe`.
trans-unit.target: It works similarly, you just pass in `raw_data` instead of `dataframe`.
